name: Grilled Spatchcocked Chicken
description: To spatchcock a chicken you need to remove the backbone of the chicken and spread it open like a book. This method for grilling a whole chicken lets the interior heat up faster and more evenly than the traditional method for a whole bird. Use your favorite rub and sauce, if you like.
recipeIngredient: ¼ cup barbecue sauce, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Place salt in a large bowl or Dutch oven and add a little water. Stir until salt is dissolved. Unwrap the chicken and place in the salt water brine. Add enough water to cover the bird and refrigerate up to 4 hours.
Remove chicken from the water, drain, and pat dry with paper towels. Place the chicken breast-side down on a clean cutting board.

Cut along both sides of the backbone of the chicken with kitchen shears. Remove bone and reserve for another use or discard. With the skin-side down, cut down into the breast bone and a bit of the cartilage above the bone about 1/4-inch deep using the tip of a sharp knife. Turn the chicken skin-side up.

Place the heel of one hand on top of the other wrist, and using the heel of the hand, press down on the center of the breast, above the area of the cut, to flatten the center and achieve a more uniform thickness of the chicken.

Combine smoked paprika, garlic powder, cumin, and pepper in a small bowl. Rub spice mix onto both sides of the chicken, gently lifting the skin wherever possible to place some of the rub directly onto the meat. Refrigerate seasoned chicken uncovered for at least 2 hours.
Remove chicken from the refrigerator 10 to 15 minutes before grilling so it can come to room temperature.
Preheat an outdoor grill for medium heat to about 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Lightly oil the grate.

Place chicken bone-side down onto the preheated grill and cook for 50 to 60 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted near the bone should read 150 degrees F (65 degrees C). Flip the chicken skin-side up and brush with barbecue sauce. Continue grilling until chicken is no longer pink at the bone and the juices run clear, about 20 more minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted near the bone should read 165 degrees F (74 degrees C).
Remove to a platter, tent with foil, and allow chicken to rest, about 10 minutes. Cut chicken into 6 servings and serve with additional barbecue sauce, if desired.

review.reviewBody: SImple, juicy, tender, full of flavor (I used a bbq rub from Buc-ee's). Temperature probe to 165. PERFECTLY DONE.

This is a good, easy to follow recipe that will give you a strong foundation to build on. It’s basic fundamentals that once mastered will allow to you hit a home run on the grill every time.
Once you master the cook, you can play around with variations on the brine, or rub for even more fantastic results. Experimenting with spritzing, mopping, and water pans with wine or beer are also possibilities with this recipe.
Happy Cooking

I'm making it tonight. But gosh, if we could just get the definition of SIDE straight. Skin side, outside, inside, breast side, one side, that side, it just goes on and on and on. It is very confusing for those of us who are inexperienced but trying to learn to cook!!

This is the best way to grill a whole chicken ?? with this exception. You do not have to remove the backbone.
With good rugged kitchen shears put the chicken on the board breast side down. Now cut all the way through one side of the backbone. Open the chicken up and slice the skin along one side of  the breast this will allow it to lay flat on the grill.
Seas9n that side (inside ) well and flip over to the skin side and season as well. Spray skin with olive oil.
Grill skin side up - slow and low until done. The skin should be crispy.

Made this for the first time tonight.  It was delicious, tender and easy.  The only change was I used some avocado oil to swab the grill grates and chicken skin before grilling   
I do have to side with a previous reviewer’s comment on what side is what. In the instructions. I personally watched 3 you tube videos tandem still had to make my best guess.  
Here goes...the first 50-60 minute cooking interval is SKIN SIDE DOWN. The second 20 minute cooking interval is bone side down. 
First interval is time or 150* in thickest part of meat   In this case it’s the breast is the thickest part. The end temperature should be a minimum of 165*
Use all burners on the grill to maintain a 375* temperature and keep grill lid closed as much as possible. 
There are also videos on You Tube on spatchcocking a chicken for those, like me, that need a video demonstrations
